query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
25 Lì si cantò non Bacco, non Peana, 26 ma tre persone in divina natura, 27 e in una persona essa e l’umana.
query.result:
**English:**
25 There they sang not of Bacchus, not of Paean, 26 but of three persons in divine nature, 27 and in one person that and the human.
**Cornish:**
25 Nans yw kanas Bacco, na Peana, 26 mes tre person yn natur dhiwin, 27 ha yn onen person ena ha'n denel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
28 Compié ’l cantare e ’l volger sua misura; 29 e attesersi a noi quei santi lumi, 30 felicitando sé di cura in cura.
query.result:
**English:**
28 The song and the turning of its measure were complete; 29 and those holy lights turned their attention to us, 30 blessing themselves from care to care.
**Cornish:**
28 Gorfenna an kan ha'n tro'ga y mesur; 29 ha'n goleuow sans owth tro'ga dhe'n ni, 30 ow bendithya aga-aga a sorg dhe sorg.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
31 Ruppe il silenzio ne’ concordi numi 32 poscia la luce in che mirabil vita 33 del poverel di Dio narrata fumi,
34 e disse: «Quando l’una paglia è trita, 35 quando la sua semenza è già riposta, 36 a batter l’altra dolce amor m’invita.
query.result:
**English:**
31 Then the light in which the wondrous life 32 of God's poor man was narrated to me 33 broke the silence among the harmonious deities,
34 and said: "When one threshing is finished, 35 when its seed is already stored, 36 sweet love invites me to thresh the other.
**Cornish:**
31 Torras an tawsow yn mysk an numi, 32 wosa an goleu ena owth istori 33 bywans gwir an den bosek a Dhu,
34 ha leverel: "Pan yw onen palva gorfen, 35 pan yw y hadow ow koveri, 36 karanteth kerensa vy dhe'n gila."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
37 Tu credi che nel petto onde la costa 38 si trasse per formar la bella guancia 39 il cui palato a tutto ’l mondo costa,
40 e in quel che, forato da la lancia, 41 e prima e poscia tanto sodisfece, 42 che d’ogne colpa vince la bilancia,
43 quantunque a la natura umana lece 44 aver di lume, tutto fosse infuso 45 da quel valor che l’uno e l’altro fece;
46 e però miri a ciò ch’io dissi suso, 47 quando narrai che non ebbe ’l secondo 48 lo ben che ne la quinta luce è chiuso.
query.result:
**English:**
37 You believe that in the breast from which the rib 38 was taken to form the lovely cheek 39 whose palate cost the whole world so dear,
40 and in that which, pierced by the lance, 41 both before and after gave such satisfaction 42 that it outweighs every fault in the balance,
43 as much light as is possible for human nature to have 44 was infused by that power which made both the one and the other;
45 and therefore look at what I said above, 46 when I related that the second did not have 47 the good that is enclosed in the fifth light.
**Cornish:**
37 Ty a grys yn an kolon ena owth tynnas 38 an asen rag furvya an fas a-berth, 39 y palas owth kostya an bys oll,
40 ha'n onen ena, owth tynnas gans an lans, 41 ow sodisfya kemmys kyns, 42 owth tremena pub pechod yn an bilan,
43 kemmys a alla dhe natur denel 44 dhe vos leun a'n goleu, oll owth infusya 45 gans an gallosow ena owth kul an dhew;
46 ha rag henna, mir dhe'n peth a leverys vy 47 pan leverys vy na wra'gas an nessa 48 an gwir a'n pympes goleu.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
49 Or apri li occhi a quel ch’io ti rispondo, 50 e vedräi il tuo credere e ’l mio dire 51 nel vero farsi come centro in tondo.
query.result:
**English:**
49 Now open your eyes to what I answer you, 50 and you will see your belief and my words 51 become true like a center in a circle.
**Cornish:**
49 Yma, agor dhewlagas dhe'n peth a leverys vy, 50 ha gwelas vy dhew gresi ha'm lavar 51 ow kul gwir kepar kres yn krug.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 Ciò che non more e ciò che può morire 53 non è se non splendor di quella idea 54 che partorisce, amando, il nostro Sire;
55 ché quella viva luce che sì mea 56 dal suo lucente, che non si disuna 57 da lui né da l’amor ch’a lor s’intrea,
58 per sua bontate il suo raggiare aduna, 59 quasi specchiato, in nove sussistenze, 60 etternalmente rimanendosi una.
query.result:
**English:**
52 That which does not die and that which can die 53 is nothing but a reflection of that idea 54 which our Lord begets, in loving;
55 for that living light which so emanates 56 from its shining source, that it is not separated 57 from it nor from the love that interpenetrates them,
58 by its goodness gathers its radiance, 59 as if reflected, into nine subsistences, 60 while remaining eternally one.
**Cornish:**
52 An peth na wra marow ha'n peth a alla 53 nyns yw mes splendor a'n idea na 54 owth purtya, yn karanteth, an Arluth;
55 rag an goleu byw na wra kemmys mea 56 a'y goleuadow, na wra disunya 57 a-gantho na a'n karanteth owth intre'ga,
58 gans y vonens owth junya y radyans, 59 kepar owth diskwedhes, yn now sussistens, 60 owth remanya bythavow onen.

**English:**
61 Then it descends to the ultimate powers, 62 down from act to act, becoming so much, 63 that it does nothing but brief contingencies;
64 and these contingencies I mean to be 65 the generated things, which the heavens produce 66 with seed and without seed, as they move.
**Cornish:**
61 Wosa henna a'dhyskynn dhe'n gallusow ughella, 62 a-woles a-woles, hag a-dhyski, 63 bys na wra dallethow byr.
64 Ha'n byr henna a styr, 65 an traow treusys, a wra gwrys 66 gans hadow po ha'n hadow, dell woles an nef.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
67 La cera di costoro e chi la duce 68 non sta d’un modo; e però sotto ’l segno 69 idëale poi più e men traluce.
query.result:
**English:**
67 The wax of these [contingencies] and he who leads them 68 do not remain in one state; and therefore under the sign 69 of the idea, now more and now less shines through.
**Cornish:**
67 An keus a'n traow ma ha'n neb a'y ledy 68 nyns eus yn un fordh; ha dre henna 69 y'n arwodh syw an menowgh trelus.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
70 Ond’ elli avvien ch’un medesimo legno, 71 secondo specie, meglio e peggio frutta; 72 e voi nascete con diverso ingegno.
query.result:
**English:**
70 Hence it happens that a single wood, 71 according to its species, bears better and worse fruit; 72 and you are born with different talents.
**Cornish:**
70 Dre henna y hwra dallethow un prenn, 71 herwydh y eghen, frooth gwell ha gwaeth; 72 ha'n why a dheuth gans dallethow clew.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
79 Però se ’l caldo amor la chiara vista 80 de la prima virtù dispone e segna, 81 tutta la perfezion quivi s’acquista.
query.result:
**English:**
79 Therefore, if the warm love disposes and marks 80 the clear vision of the first virtue, 81 all perfection is acquired there.
**Cornish:**
79 Mes mar teu an karanteth tomm an golon kler 80 a'n kynsa gallusow a ordena ha merkya, 81 an perffethter oll a dheuth eno.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
88 Or s’i’ non procedesse avanti piùe, 89 ‘Dunque, come costui fu sanza pare?’ 90 comincerebber le parole tue.
query.result:
**English:**
88 Now if I did not proceed further, 89 ‘Then how was this man without equal?’ 90 your words would begin.
**Cornish:**
88 Mes mar na veu vy ow tos yn pella, 89 ‘Pyth, pyth veu an den-ma heb par?’ 90 thu a leveraf dhe lavarow dha.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 Ma perché paia ben ciò che non pare, 92 pensa chi era, e la cagion che ’l mosse, 93 quando fu detto “Chiedi”, a dimandare.
query.result:
**English:**
91 But so that what does not appear may seem clear, 92 consider who he was, and the reason that moved him, 93 when he was told “Ask”, to make his request.
**Cornish:**
91 Mes rag henna dhe weles kler an peth na wel, 92 meurysi pyw veu, ha’n acheson a’y movas, 93 pan veu leverys “Gofyn”, rag gofyn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
109 Con questa distinzion prendi ’l mio detto; 110 e così puote star con quel che credi 111 del primo padre e del nostro Diletto.
query.result:
**English:**
109 With this distinction, take my statement; 110 and thus it can stand with what you believe 111 about the first father and our Beloved.
**Cornish:**
109 Gans anedhra ma'th leverel an lavarow; 110 ha'gan henna y hallerdh gans henna 111 a-dro dhe'n kynsa tas ha'gan Karrek.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
112 E questo ti sia sempre piombo a’ piedi, 113 per farti mover lento com’ uom lasso 114 e al sì e al no che tu non vedi:
115 ché quelli è tra li stolti bene a basso, 116 che sanza distinzione afferma e nega 117 ne l’un così come ne l’altro passo;
118 perch’ elli ’ncontra che più volte piega 119 l’oppinïon corrente in falsa parte, 120 e poi l’affetto l’intelletto lega.
query.result:
**English:**
112 And let this always be a weight upon your feet, 113 to make you move slowly like a weary man 114 and to the yes and the no that you do not see:
115 for he who affirms and denies without distinction 116 is rightly among the fools, 117 in the one way as in the other;
118 because he often finds that the common opinion 119 leans toward the false side, 120 and then his intellect is bound by his emotions.
**Cornish:**
112 Ha henna bos bys vyth pub tra'th dhe'th treys, 113 rag dhe'th gul ow kul ow den marow, 114 dhe dhe'n 'ya ha'n 'na gwel.
115 Rag henna yw ynter an folys vyth isel, 116 neb a wra dhe'n kynsa ha'n wra dhe'n nessa, 117 y'n un fordh ha'n wra y'n fordh aral.
118 Rag yma henna a gav bos meur a-ugh, 119 an breder a-dro dhe'n fordh kamm, 120 ha henna a wra dhe'n emlow dhe'n breder.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
121 Vie più che ’ndarno da riva si parte, 122 perché non torna tal qual e’ si move, 123 chi pesca per lo vero e non ha l’arte.
query.result:
**English:**
121 In vain does one set out from the shore, 122 for he does not return as he sets out, 123 who fishes for the truth and does not have the skill.
**Cornish:**
121 Mwy ages na dhyworth an fordh yma, 122 rag ny wodhedh efan ha'n fordh, 123 neb a bysk ryb gwir ha nyns eus an arta.

**English:**
124 And of this there are clear proofs in the world: 125 Parmenides, Melissus, and Bryson, and many others, 126 who went forth and did not know where;
127 so did Sabellius and Arius and those fools 128 who were like swords to the Scriptures, 129 in twisting the right meanings.
**Cornish:**
124 Ha dhe'n keth yw kler provyans y'n an bys, 125 Parmenides, Melissus ha Brisso ha meur erel, 126 a-dro ha ny wodhons le may.
127 Henna a wrug Sabellius ha Arius ha'n folys erel 128 a veu dellow dhe'n Skryftur, 129 y'n troha an kethow gwir.

**English:**
130 Let people not be too sure yet 131 in judging, like those who assess 132 the crops in the field before they are ripe;
133 for I have seen all winter long 134 the thorn appear harsh and fierce, 135 and then bear the rose on its top;
136 and I have seen a ship, once straight and swift, 137 sail the sea for its entire journey, 138 only to perish at the end, at the mouth of the harbor.
**Cornish:**
130 Na wra an dusyansow bythkweth surel, 131 y'n brederi, avel henna neb a wra 132 an edhon y'n an park kyns bydhons ryp.
133 Rag y'm eus gweles an gwav-haval oll 134 an pren a-dhyskwedhes kalet ha garow, 135 ha wosa henna a-dhybri an ros war an kodha.
136 Ha pren a-weles vy efan ha byw, 137 a-hedhi an mor rag an fordh oll, 138 a-beri dhe'n diwedh y'n myns an aber.
